description: On March 15, 2020, Czech government banned free movement to its minimum from midnight on March 16 until March 24, all individuals must stay home except for specified exemptions. The service rounds of police officers, doctors or social workers are of course also allowed, as are individual walks in parks or in the countryside.
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: On March 16, 2020, the Government of Czech Republic recommended for individuals over 70 years of age not to go outside their homes for the duration of the emergency, with the exception of a visit to a health facility to ensure emergency medical care.
The government of Czechia announced in 18th of March 2020 that the stay-at-home order is continued, and there will be stricter the conditions for individuals who commute across the border.
As announced on 18th of March 2020,  only elderly  individuals who are over 65 can enter establishments, grocery shops, post offices and pharmacies between 10:00-12:00 as of Thursday.

On March 15, 2020, Czech government banned free movement to its minimum from midnight on March 16 until March 24, all individuals must stay home except for specified exemptions. The service rounds of police officers, doctors or social workers are of course also allowed, as are individual walks in parks or in the countryside. UPDATE: The original end date of the lockdown was set to be on March 24, 2020, it has been extended to April 1, 2020.
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: On March 15, 2020, Czech government banned free movement to its minimum from midnight on March 16 until March 24, all individuals must stay home except for specified exemptions. The service rounds of police officers, doctors or social workers are of course also allowed, as are individual walks in parks or in the countryside. UPDATE: This was supposed to end on April 1, 2020, but now extended to April 11, 2020.

description: The stay-at-home order is continued and starting from 7th of April 2020, people can do outdoor exercises alone (non-contact) without face masks in Czechia.

On March 15, 2020, Czech government banned free movement to its minimum from midnight on March 16 until March 24, all individuals must stay home except for specified exemptions. The service rounds of police officers, doctors or social workers are of course also allowed, as are individual walks in parks or in the countryside. UPDATE: This was supposed to end on  April 11, 2020, but now extended to April 20, 2020.
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: As of 24 April 2020, in Czechia free movement of people outside is possible for groups of up to and including 10 people.

On March 16, 2020, the Government of Czech Republic recommended for individuals over 70 years of age not to go outside their homes for the duration of the emergency, with the exception of a visit to a health facility to ensure emergency medical care. UPDATE: This policy was repealed on May 18, 2020.
In Czechia, starting from 25th of May 2020, visits to medical and social facilities are permitted.

The government of the Czech Republic prohibits the free movement of people throughout the country between 9:00 p.m. to 04:59 a.m., from 4th of October 2020 till 20th of November 2020, with the exceptions: urgent trips; travel to work; performing occupation and  serving activities; walking dogs within 500 meters of their home.

On October 21, 2020, Czech Republic announced further restrictions following a general meeting, to come into force on the 22nd from 6am. 'The free movement of persons throughout the Czech Republic is prohibited', although there are exceptions to this ban, including: trips to work and in connection with business, trips to see family, purchase of basic necessities and trips to healthcare facilities, to go to parks/nature, to go to holiday cottages if staying there.
The policy is slated to end on November 3, at 23:59 o'clock.
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: In Czechia, visits to accused in remand prisons, to serving prisoners and to inmates in pre-trial detention will be banned starting from October 23, 2020.
From 18 to 20 November 2020, in Czechia, the stay-at-home order is amended to allow up to 15 guests at weddings as well as to allow athletes to participate in outdoor competitions.

As of 16 December 2020, in Czechia the clients of old peoples homes and homes providing special treatment will be able to leave the building or grounds of the facility in which they receive social services if conditions as per article 2, numbers 1 to 3 of Government Resolution 532/2020 Sb. are met.
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: As of 16 December 2020, in Czechia the clients of old peoples homes and homes providing special treatment will be able to leave the building or grounds of the facility in which they receive social services if conditions as per article 2, numbers 1 to 3 of Government Resolution 532/2020 Sb. are met. UPDATE: From December 22, 2020, the condition that the 1st outing within 6 hours will be allowed and symptoms of COVID-19 will be monitored upon return is removed. Now, every walk outside of the premises where the client lives will only be allowed on the condition that the user is placed in a segregated area immediately upon return and that the first antigenic POC test is performed within 72 hours of the end of the walk and repeated in another 3 to 4 days; the segregated area will be terminated if both tests are negative.
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: On January 30, 2021, Czech government applied a new lockdown condition, from midnight on Friday to Saturday, people can travel to their cottages and chalets, but only members of one household may stay there. The government also ordered that people limit contacts with non-household members to what is strictly necessary and strongly recommended that people stay at their place of residence only with members of their own household and persons cared for by the household member, and that persons use a respirator without an exhalation valve of class FFP2 or KN95. The rules for the stay of foreigners in the Czech Republic are also being tightened.
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: On January 30, 2021, Czech government applied a new lockdown condition, from midnight on Friday to Saturday, people can travel to their cottages and chalets, but only members of one household may stay there. The government also ordered that people limit contacts with non-household members to what is strictly necessary and strongly recommended that people stay at their place of residence only with members of their own household and persons cared for by the household member, and that persons use a respirator without an exhalation valve of class FFP2 or KN95. The rules for the stay of foreigners in the Czech Republic are also being tightened. UPDATE: The original policy's restriction exceptions did not include travel for the purpose of elections and meetings of legal entities and their holding but in the change of the policy, travel for the purpose of elections and meetings of legal entities and their holding are now allowed.
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

UPDATE: This policy was repealed on February 15, 2021.

description: On February 14, 2021, Czech government announced that now included travel for the purpose of elections and meetings of legal entities and their holding in their exceptions for free movement restrictions. Started from February 15, 2021 and ended on February 28, 2021.
From 15 to 28 of February 2021 in Czechia, people cannot leave their houses unless on strictly essential business, which includes travel for the purpose of elections and meetings of legal bodies.

From 10 March 2021, a ban on leaving the (permanent) residence district (or, in case of the capital city of Prague as a place of residence, the city) applies to all persons throughout the Czechia. People can also leave their residence between 11 o'clock in the evening and 5 o'clock in the morning for urgent reasons (e.g. a visit to a hospital, floods, etc.).
Starting from Monday, 22th of March 2021, the government of Czechia allowed people to go on trips to nature or to exercise on the territory of the entire district.
In Czechia, people may leave their house in order to travel to or participate in church services from 9pm to 12am on the days of April 1-3 2021.
